Award.AwardTitle: NSF East Asia and Pacific Summer Institute for FY 2012 in Taiwan
Award.AbstractNarration:
This action funds Matthew Campbell of the University of Alaska, Fairbanks to conduct a research project during the summer of 2012. The research address the question: "Did flatfish evolve more than once?" The host scientist is Dr. Wei-Jen Chen of the Institute of Oceanography, National Taiwan University in Taipei, Taiwan.

Intellectual Merit lies in the investigation of the apparent contradiction of information from anatomical and molecular studies. In classification schemes, the flatfish (Pleuronectiformes) are all considered to have evolved from a common ancestor. That is, all living species of flatfish are descendants from a single lineage that evolved a compressed body design. This idea of flatfish monophyly is supported by the physical form of flatfish, however molecular studies indicate that flatfish likely evolved more than once. Some flatfish appear to be more closely related to non-flatfish than to other flatfish. The research is identifying evolutionary origins and relationships of flatfish.

Broader impacts of an EAPSI fellowship includes a first-hand research experience outside the U.S.; an introduction to the science, science policy, and scientific infrastructure of the respective location; and an orientation to the society, culture and language. These activities meet the NSF goal to educate for international collaborations early in the career of its scientists, engineers, and educators, thus ensuring a globally aware U.S. scientific workforce.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This award provided funding for me to work in a Taiwanese lab for eight weeks during the summer of 2012.  Additional support in Taiwan was provided by the Taiwanese National Science Foundation.

I visited the lab of Dr. Wei-Jen Chen, Institute of Oceanography, National Taiwan University. Since then, I have collaborated with Dr. Chen on a paper which was accepted for publication in Molecular Phylogenetics and Evolution, submitted in April of 2013.

The focus of the work I conducted with Dr. Chen was on flatfish evolutionary relationships. There is evidence from molecular studies that flatfish may belong to two separate lineages.  We investigated this possibility by using a large molecular dataset compiled by Dr. Chen bolstered with some data generation I did.  We constructed a dataset robust against many possible biases, and analyzed the molecular sequence data under a variety of frameworks and models. Consistently, we found evidence for two independent origins of flatfish.  Furthermore, divergence time estimation of flatfish lineages indicates they are much older than existing fossils.

Dr. Chen and I are continuing our work by using the same dataset with a slight expansion to understand the relationships within one particular lineage of flatfishes (approximately 700 species represented by ~25 key representatives).  We are planning on addressing many of the same potential biases as encountered in our previous work to provide a detailed hypothesis of the relationships of this group.

The EAPSI project has been a great experience for me, and has helped me in many ways. Working with Dr. Chen has been very helpful for me to learn a great deal about "acanthomorph" fishes and how to write, submit, and respond to criticisms of scientific manuscripts. I highly recommend the EAPSI program to any graduate student in the sciences.
